content.description: Use a tree and stem up to the first bolt, then climb block terrain on the face, placing a small cam or nut if desired, then stand up on those blocks and clip your next bolt, Make crimpy and cryptic moves up the face to a good stance and rest up. Follow more bolts through slabbier terrain up and right to another cruxy section and a spooky mantle. Bolt anchor on a ledge can be used to traverse way left and access the upper two pitches of Gunslinger (12a). This pitch is super exciting and quite tricky, don't be surprised if you whip at the finish.
content.protection: One small cam, and quickdraws for bolts.
content.location: Located to the right of where you pop up on the ledge if you take the scramble way up. One bolted route left of Head Cement (10d), or two routes left of the second pitch of The Eliminate.

content.description: Start from a spacious belay on the terrace, and go up the trivial looking blocky start. With effort clip the first bolt, and enter a hard sequence to a good hold. Clip bolt two, and hopelessly gaze up the rest of the route, noting the ground-fall territory between bolts 2 and 3. Bail, or enter into some pumpy, desperate feeling laybacking, followed by more hard slab climbing to an exciting finish.
content.protection: 5 Bolts, big space between bolts 2 and 3. I'd recommend bringing a long stick clip to clean and work this thing on TR before a lead.
content.location: Find the line of bolts on the wonderwall terrace to left of the 4th class section between the upper and lower ledges.

content.description: The Wonder Wall Terrace is a large ledge with many excellent hard face climbs. At its right most edge lies the second pitch of The Eliminate, and at its left most edge is a blank wall filled with forgotten projects. The lower tier contains the routes near Head Cement, and the Upper Tier starts with London Calling. Â This spacious ledge is a great place to hang out in the early season as all these routes dry out very fast, and the place catches a lot of sun. in the very early or very late season I recommend hauling a bag of warm layers and food up there, and making a day of it.
